title: dons defeat dundee after extra time at dens park
story: Aberdeen produced a dramatic comeback at Dens Park to defeat Dundee - and reach the Betfred Cup quarter-finals.The Dons required extra-time to get past Championship opposition in the City of Discovery.Danny Johnson had put Dundee in front from the penalty spot just before half-time.It looked asthere wasn#t going to be a route back into the tie for Derek McInnes# men. but Andy Considine equalised in injury time and Sam Cosgrove grabbed the winner in extra-time.Aberdeen will tackle Hearts at Tynecastle in the last-eight of the League Cup.The Reds# only change from Thursday#s - Europa League loss to Rijeka at Pittodrie was summer signing Craig Bryson coming in for his first start in midfield with Lewis Ferguson suspended.Dundee enjoyed the better of the first half and had a couple of decent chances to open the scoring in the first quarter.On  minutes Declan McDaid crossed from the left and Josh Todd sent the ball just wide at the back post from close range.Six minutes later it was the woodwork which thwarted the Championship outfit.Jamie Ness rolled a pass into Johnson who turned Considine on the edge of the area, but the striker#s left foot shot struck the right post and bounced clear.Aberdeen also survived a penalty shoot for apparent handball by midfielder Funso Ojo before falling behind a minute from the interval.Considine pulled Jordon Forster to the deck at a free-kick from Ness, ref WIllie Collum  pointed to the penalty spot and Johnson made no mistake from  yards finding the bottom right corner.The Dons started the second period at a higher tempo with Sam Cosgrove shooting wide soon after the break and Jon Gallagher#s low effort straight at keeper Jack Hamilton in the rd minute.Dundee remained stubborn in defence and with Aberdeen looking to push on in the closing stages showed they could be a threat on the counter-attack with McDaid#s dipping shot from  yards just over.The Reds could have levelled with eight minutes left when sub Connor McLennan was released down the right, he cut inside and had a shot blocked with Gallagher heading the loose ball towards goal and Jordon Forster clearing off the line.Just when it looked like that might be that Aberdeen saved themselves in the first of four added minutes. Ojo#s free-kick was met powerfully by the head of Greg Leigh, Hamilton made a save ing to his right, but Gallagher played the ball back across goal and Considine managed to force it home from a couple of yards.After the boost forcing extra time you expected Aberdeen to be stronger in the additional period and they were.Two minutes before half-time in extra time they hit the front when Leigh got to the bye-line down the left and his deep cross found Cosgrove at the back post and the striker headed down and into the bottom left corner.In the second half of extra time Dundee threw everything at the Dons, but they held firm to get through.Dundee: Jack Hamilton, Cammy Kerr, Jordan McGhee, Jordon Forster, Jordan Marshall, Josh Todd , Shaun Byrne, Finlay Robertson , Jamie Ness , Declan McDaid, Danny Johnson .Subs not used: Calum Ferrie, Max Anderson, Michael Cunningham.Aberdeen: Joe Lewis, Shay Logan, Andy Considine, Scott McKenna, Greg Leigh, Funso Ojo, Craig Bryson , Jon Gallagher , Ryan Hedges , Niall McGinn , Sam Cosgrove.Subs not used: Tomas Cerny, Scott Wright, Curtis Main.

title: student dives in with plan for historic north east pool
story: A student was inspired by her brother to come up with new designs for a beloved north-east pool.Nichaela Richardson drafted up the plans for Tarlair swimming pool as part of her final year project at Napier University in Edinburgh.She grew up in Macduff and the site was one of her favourite childhood places to visit.The interior and spatial design graduate was inspired by her brother Kieran, who suffers from a medical condition, to come up with plans to give the pool a new lease of le. vw, px"  She said: “Kieran has ADHD and I think it’s a condition which is widely known but it’s not completely understood.“A lot of people think it is down to bad behaviour and you get medicinal treatment but then you are left to it. I wanted to create a sensory environment that would help build up the confidence of sufferers.“It can be hard for Kieran, who is , to focus in school, so having a space you can go to and interact with people and not be isolated helps people like him get away from things they find hard in day-to-day le.”Miss Richardson, , carried out research into attention deficit hyperactivity disorderfor her dissertation before taking on the design project and found very few sensory rooms were tailored towards people with the condition. vw, px"  Her concepts focused on people having space to explore and take part in interactive play.She said: “I visited the site to see where I could use the water and the colours and create something that would be a bit dferent.“Once it was completed, I was invited to showcase the work with classmates at the  Interior Design at Free Range degree show in London.“Tarlair has been such an influential place to me, so it has been really good to showcase it, letting people know how nice it is and then showing my designs.“I added in an underwater floor and ided up the building, but it just shows it could become anything.”Miss Richardson received a first-class honours for her Edinburgh Napier degree when she graduated last month and is now a qualied interior and spatial designer.An annual gala event will be held on Sunday from noon to pm to raise money for the Friends of Tarlair group set up in  to bring the much-loved pool back into use.

title: letters week 24
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,Further to your article #Three amigos clean up in Lochgilphead#, Friday May , I would like to add the lane behind Lochgilphead Bowling Club is often filled with fresh poo.I#m sick of coming over nearly every day and finding poo all over the lane. The lane floods, so between trying to dodge puddles, you land in dog dirt.I wish they would fix the path because a lot of people use it, some of them pensioners with or parents with prams.Celia MacFarlane, Lochgilphead.Sir,Seven out of ten people with diabetes feel overwhelmed by the demands of their condition and this signicantly affects their mental and physical health.That is why we are calling for new national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health support and to increase support available in Argyll to people living with diabetes.As part of Diabetes UK’s Diabetes Weekwe are urging people in Argyll to #SeeDiabetesDferently and back our campaign for national standards for diabetes mental health support and services.Our recently published research revealed the relentless nature of diabetes can impact people’s emotional well-being and mental health, ranging from day-to-day frustration and low mood, to specic psychological and mental health dficulties including clinical depression and anxiety.The findings, published in the report #Too often missing: Making emotional and psychological support routine in diabetes care#, show that diabetes is much more than a physical condition – and that emotional and psychological demands of living with diabetes should be recognised and support provided.Diabetes Scotland is urgently calling on the NHS to create national standards for diabetes emotional and mental health services. These should ensure everyone receives #joined up# care, that they are asked how they are feeling as part of every diabetes appointment and that a mental health professional with knowledge of diabetes is part of every diabetes care team.To sign our petition, go to diabetes.org.uk missingAngela Mitchell, National Director of Diabetes Scotland.Sir,I#m asking residents in the Highlands and Islands to give their views on Conservative proposals for tackling serious crime.In order to provide Scotland with an alternative to Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP in , we are keen to gain feedback from as many people to our policy proposals to make them as relevant as possible to the needs and aspirations of everyone in Scotland.Too many people in Scotland are affected by the behaviour of serious criminals. This needs to be properly addressed and my colleague Liam Kerr MSP, shadow Justice Secretary, has outlined key policy proposals in a member#s bill in the Scottish Parliament to tackle this scourge.It would give Scottish judges the power to impose whole le sentences to those convicted of the most serious violent and sexual crimes including the murder of a police officer.The courts would still have discretion to impose the appropriate sentence based on all the facts of each case, as they do in England and Wales where such a provision already exists.The proposed Whole Le CustodyBill will not mean the perpetrators of a particular crime will always receive a whole le sentence, but rather that the courts will have the power to impose one where there is sufficient justication.We have started the consultation and experts and members of the public are invited to register their views.Email me at donald.cameron.msp@parliament.scot or write to me at Donald Cameron MSP,  George Street, Oban, PA NT, with your views.MSP Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands.Sir,The SNP has warned Scotland’s NHS is under threat from a Tory-Trump trade deal that could leave the Scottish Government without a veto over a post-Brexit deal that sells Scotland out.This stark warning follows the revelations from Donald Trump that in terms of trade deals, everything, including the NHS, would be on the table.At Prime Ministers Questions, SNP Deputy Westminster Leader Kirsty Blackman MP said Donald Trump and the Tories could not be trusted on the NHS and criticised the UK government for plotting to take powers away from the Scottish Parliament that would allow it to safeguard Scotland’s NHS.The threats to Scotland#s NHS are growing under the prospect of a hard-right Tory-Trump Brexit trade deal. Those threats could undermine the integrity and independence of our Scottish NHS.The UK Tories will block any potential veto by the Scottish Government over such a damaging deal.The SNP government will fight to the end to defend Scotland#s public services from this unprecedented Tory Brexit danger. Our NHS must remain in public hands. It is not, and should never be, up for sale.Scotland has been completely ignored throughout the Brexit process and Tory plans to grab powers from the Scottish Parliament will leave us even more exposed.It is clearer than ever that the only way to properly protect Scotland#s interests, and keep our NHS in public hands, is with the full powers of independence.MP Brendan O#Hara, Argyll and Bute.

story: Barabel McKayUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsLast year we were studying the Argyll and Bute Health and Social Care Partnership#Transforming Together#   document, which presented a vision of combining our will and skills to create a healthy future for the citizens of Argyll.The promises in that did not translate into reality.Now, a  beautully constructed and presented Living Well document is available. It runs to  pages, and must have taken signicant time and money to produce.It relies heavily on community participation and the Third Sector Interface .While it was being prepared the HSCP was in the process of getting rid of volunteer forums, TSI was shedding staff and Guided Self Help was being transferred to the NHS Mental Health Team, while essential services are still dependent on successful bids for money.Planning must not be a substitute for provision. In Living Well we are told that hypertension is by far the most common long-term condition. This area lacks the yearly health checks which might lead to early detection and intervention.The initiative and enthusiasm of hospital staff in improving mobility have already been commended, but the dearth of professional rehabilitation services in the community is nothing short of a disgrace.Everyone  seems to recognise this # indeed at a recent housing conference the keynote speaker highlighted the need for intervention to halt the downward slide into dependency. In an English trust they have even  appointed a physiotherapist to identy reversible causes of frailty.We have to fight complacency about our own health and in the attitudes of our health care providers.To contact Mid Argyll Health and Care Forum, email the forum chairperson Barabel McKay at barabelmck@gmail

title: a note of chamber music coming to crear
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe UK’s leading string orchestra, the Scottish Ensemble , has announced the first half of Scottish tour  # and Argyll is on the list of venues.The ensemble will perform Mendelssohn and Enescu’s stunning octets, and will be led by the outstanding Norwegian violinist Marianne Thorsen.Though written for just eight instruments, both of these sophisticated works have the drama, richness and depth of a full-blown symphony. They also make for an excellently contrasting pair.From Mendelssohn’s exuberant opening bars, we are swept through music that is complex yet captivatingly, joyously melodic throughout, while Enescu’s is moody, breathlessly dramatic and, in parts, simply volcanic.Guest directed by Marianne Thorsen, SE will explore the specic charm of seeing a small group of musicians performing live. With fewer instruments, the fabric of the music becomes more tangible, subtle shts in mood may have a new-found presence, and pieces you think you know well might offer surprising new colours when heard live. With fewer musicians on stage, it is easier to follow each inidual path and witness the beautul alchemy of eight artists creating something together.Thorsen is an acclaimed soloist and passionate chamber musician. Former leader of the Nash Ensemble, she regularly performs with Norway’s Trondheim Soloists, one of the founding ensembles of The Bridge network and festival.The first half of the tour, which is called Chamber Notes, will call at Crear Studio, Kilberry, on August , followed by a performance at Mull Theatre, Tobermory, on August  before moving on to Inverness and Dundee.Other Scottish dates, including Edinburgh and Glasgow, are programmed for February .PIC:Marianne Thorsen. no_aMarianne Thorsen

title: letters to the editor august 16 2019
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I would like to record my thanks to everyone who contributed to the running of the Mid Argyll Show this year.It is great for visitors to see these traditions and talent brought together and seeing young people participating in events assuring that these customs are in safe hands for the future.Thank you again to all involved in running the show.Councillor Anne HornSir,I read with some interest that a new dentist was coming to town in Lochgilphead to set up a practice, which I am sure we look forward to.The local NHS trust cannot seem to lure one to the area to work at the Mid Argyll Hospital practice, which I think is unfortunate for all concerned. We do at the moment have a dentist and fully qualied staff and are happy with their work.Rumour has it that the aforementioned dentist and staff will be taking on patients from Mid Argyll Hospital, which I presume they tend to already.But the practice is to lose its local NHS patients, so they will deal solely with patients who require dental treatment from the hospital. I think this situation leaves the NHS patients in limbo.I am sure we would rather that the current dentist and all of her staff be given a chance to voice their opinions on this matter as much and as well as the local populace.Yes, it will be brilliant to have both dentists in the town. There is the possibility that those on the local list who are currently treated well by the dental department at the hospital maybe still seen by the dentist and her staff, but I would like this to be confirmed by the local NHS trust.Brian MacDonald, CrinanSir,Hundreds of people across Scotland have been helped through their exam results by a local group of Skills Development Scotlandcareers advisers.Based across the north of Scotland, the advisers were part of a team taking calls at the SDS Exam Results Helpline from am on results day.The helpline is a vital service, supporting young people and their families at what can be one of the most stressful times of their lives.Expert advice and guidance is available all year round, not just on results day.Our professionally qualied careers advisers are working in every state secondary school in Scotland and from our network of high street centres across the country.In schools, careers services are delivered one-to-one, in classrooms and at school events across all year groups, supporting young people to develop the skills to make informed career decisions throughout their lives. There is also support for parents and carers.At SDS centres customers can get information, advice and guidance about jobs, the local labour market, training courses and apprenticeships as well as how to prepare for interviews and help with CVs and applications.The work of SDS careers advisers in schools and centres is supported by Scotland’s careers website myworldofwork, where you can access advice  hours a day. It is packed with career information, advice and tools such as the CV builder. There is also a dedicated exam results section.Details of the local SDS centres are available at myworldofwork centres and information about events and opportunities is also available on Facebook.Pauline Graham, Project Manager for the SDS Exam Results HelplineSir,I had a great time at this year#s Islay Show. It was fantastic to speak to so many of my constituents.It was also wonderful to see many local business stalls promoting Islay#s dynamic and booming economy.The show was well attended with lots of families, both local and visitors, having a fun day out and luckily the sun was shining most of the day.A huge thanks to all the organisers and everyone  who contributed to the event.Councillor Alastair RedmanSir,I have real concerns about the deteriorating condition of some Argyll cemeteries.Constituents from Islay recently joined Councillor Alastair Redman in highlighting the poor upkeep of cemeteries in the area he represents.Councillor Redman reported that there were also problems at other cemeteries in his ward, including the cemetery at Carradale in East Kintyre.I understand that Argyll and Bute Council confirmed that they now, at last, have plans in place to address the problems at Kilnaughton.It remains disappointing, however, that things are allowed to deteriorate to the extent that the maintenance of cemeteries has become a matter of public concern.Frankly, it is very surprising that a cemetery where interments are actually still taking place has been undermined in this way and there must surely be an obligation to ensure this doesn’t happen.My experience is that communities in the Highlands and Islands pay special regard to the final resting places of fellow members of their communities and will be perplexed to discover that they appear to be uncared-for.Donald Cameron, Highlands and Islands MSP

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe search operation continues for a -year-old man reported missing after a boat capsized on Loch Awe.The emergency services received reports at around .pm on Saturday August  that a boat with three men on board had capsized.Two men, aged  and , managed to swim to a nearby island in the loch, where they raised the alarm and from where they were rescued and taken by ambulance to Lorn and Islands Hospital in Oban.Both men have now been discharged from hospital.A police spokesperson said: #A multi-agency search for the third man, aged , involving specialist police search teams and the Maritime and Coastguard Agency, resumed this morning .#Enquiries in to the circumstances surrounding the incident are continuing.#Photo: Kevin McGlynn.

title: horse-charity-39-s-last-gasp-bid-clear-final-fundraising-hurdle
story: A HORSE-RIDING charity which has supported hundreds of disadvantaged youngsters is facing a race against time.Stable Le has been providing equine assisted learning ever since growing out of the Gala Youth project more than a decade ago.But central to its courses and therapies at its Ashkirk base is an indoor riding school.And much of Stable Les income is also generated from commercial clients who use the facility.Mags Powell from Stable Le told us: "Our indoor riding school is over  years old and is in need of an essential renovation."The structure needs to be strengthened to make it wind and water tight, the roof and windows leak and urgently need to be replaced."The building is currently dark, damp and cold."We are very worried thatthe building is left to deteriorate further we will not be able to support the  or so vulnerable young people referred to us each year."Over the past few months staff at the charity have been developing plans to secure and future-proof the indoor school.Having already held fundraising events and securing pound, from Scottish Borders Councils Localities Bid Fund, they are now attempting to find the final pound, required through an online Crowdfunding appeal.But time is running out.Mags added: "The Crowdfunding campaign will only be fundedthe final pound, is pledged before August ."Any amount of pledge would be very welcome and there are some lovely rewards generously donated from ious companies and iniduals up for grabs."Despite the major fundraising campaign and worries over the future of its indoor riding school, Stable Le has continued to support support young people and their families who are experiencing personal challenges.Their equine assisted learning allows each student to discover a sense of self, build resilience and learn transferable le skills while working with horses.An ongoing Out of the Woods project, which will run until next March gives young people the opportunity to gain an SQA Level  qualication in Horse Care.The first class of eight students started the course in January with all of them making the grade.Stable Le team leader Cindy Davie said: ldquoThe NPA Level  in Horse Care was developed for learners who found a classroom environment a barrier to learning."All of our students attended for a full day, completing work on the yard, riding lessons, and a small amount of cabin based activities."As with every new venture there are teething problems, however our students engaged and worked their way through them."Feedback from families and referring agencies commented on the growth of confidence of the young people."They developed from a very quiet group of iniduals in to a whole bundle of fun and laughter! All eight learners completed the units, and had a pathway for future learning in place."A second group of students is currently working towards the qualication, with a further class set to start later this month.Cindy added: "Staff are currently undergoing training to be able to deliver Youth Achievement Awards, which we hope to be able to ersy and offer through our Environmental and Leskills groups, as well as the Horse Care."We would like to say a huge thank you to Borders College for their support, and external verication, and we look forward to growing together in the future.To support Stable Les appeal indoor riding school appeal go to www.crowdfunder stable-le-save-our-school

title: isabelle-39-s-design-collecting-accolades
story: A PEEBLES pupil has designs on donations at Tweeddale Museum and Gallery.Fth year pupil Isabelle Elsmore was tasked with making something on the theme of the The Great Outdoors for her National  Design and Manufacture portfolio.The team at Tweeddale Museum were in need of a new donation box and they had already approached Peebles High Schools technology department to seepupils would be interested in creating one.When Isabelle approached staff with her design brief they were delighted with her plans.Isabellersquos design incorporates branches, twigs and leaves, which not only celebrate The Great Outdoors, but also complement the current exhibition, Intertwined, in which textile artists Rose Campbell and Alison King take inspiration from the beautul forests surrounding Peebles.Assistant curator Phoebe Stewart: "Itrsquos wonderful for Tweeddale museum to work collaboratively with Peebles High School - and what a wonderful outcome for all involved.ldquoAs a charity, Live Borders aims to invest in the local community, and we are so pleased with our new box from the very talented Isabelle!ldquoWe would like to thank staff at Peebles High School for their co-operation and we wish Isabelle all the best in her future career and plans."Without doubt she is very creative and talented, and who knows, maybe one day she will exhibit more of her work at Tweeddale Museum.

title: entries-open-borders-ms-fun-run
story: IT has become one of the most recognisable races in the Borders.And yet again the orange-topped athletes will be raising vital funds for the Multiple Sclerosis Society Borders group.On Sunday, September  the th Borders MS Fun Run will get underway at Priorwood House in Melrose.And yet again the km run will be sponsored by JS Crawford developers.Judy Eglington from the MS Society Borders group told us: "The fun run will once again raise money so that we can provide very beneficial therapies for people affected by MS in the Borders."These therapies help people affected by MS to retain some independence and sense of well being."Among the services provided for MS sufferers are hydrotherapy, power-plate sessions, yoga classes, physiotherapy, remedial massage, aromatherapy and reflexology.But it all comes at a cost.Judy added: "Our hydrotherapy is particularly beneficial to people with MS who have very limited mobility as they are able to walk-in the pool something they are unable to do on dry land."The annual cost of the therapies are approximately pound, so the group is delighted with the huge amount of support that they receive from people in the Borders."The group also provides emotional and practical support including accessing grants."The Borders MS Fun Run is open to everyone and is both wheelchair and dog friendly.This years runners will come under starters orders at noon on September .Further information and entry forms are available from www.jscrawfordAnyone affected by MS can get further information on MS Society Borders group at borders@mssociety.org.uk

title: 50-green-homes-built-borders-next-year
story: UP to  energy efficient, affordable homes are set to be built in the Borders next year.Eildon Housing association has announced it will create the new houses set across four communities.And Innerleithen and Broughton are on the list along with Westruther and Denholm.A spokesperson for the social landlord said: "Warmer, cheaper, more affordable homes is something we all want, and this could be a reality as Eildon Housing look at future house building and its impact on the environment."The need for affordable housing in the Borders has hit an all-time high, with recent figures showing, on average,  people bidding for every home that becomes available."To meet this need it is important to be able to build a house quicker and make it cheaper to heat and therefore eradicate fuel poverty especially in rural parts of the Borders reducing our use of fossil fuels."Working in partnership with Scottish Borders Council, Construction Scotland Innovation Centre and Glasgow School of Art, the new developments will be part of a study to compare construction costs, time to build, living quality, and whether the homes are financially viable to build.The spokesperson added: "The developments at Westruther, Broughton, Denholm and Innerleithen will see up to  new green homes built and will test dferent building methods from passivhaus, energiesprong, volumetric and the traditional build wersquore all used to."Potential new tenants will be heavily involved in the study for a period of time when they move in, as the results will be used to determine not only the future building programme for Eildon, but also lead the way for how Scottish homes are built and lived in, in the future."

title: end-road-peebles-british-legion
story: VETERANS in Peebles have confirmed that the towns branch of the Royal British Legion is to close later this year.For more than nine decades the armed forces charity has helped thousands of former service personnel in and around Peebles.And its members have played a key part in maintaining the regions War Memorials as well as raising vital funds.But with membership numbers dropping each year - currently standing at  - and dficulties in recruiting post holders, time has been called on the local organisation.Mike Stark, who has been at the forefront of keeping the Peebles branch operating, told us: "We have an ageing membership - many of us are in our s and s - and finding people to take on committee posts such as chair or treasurer has been a struggle."It is with a great deal of sadness that this decision has been made."The Royal British Legion was founded in  to help survivors of World War One as well as their families.A sale of poppies each year has allowed that work to continue for servicemen and and women ing from more modern wars, with around , branches still operating across the country.The Peebles branch of the Royal British Legion Scotland will officially close on October .Prior to the winding up, a laying of the branchs Colours ceremony will take place at Peebles Parish Church on Sunday, September .The flags will be permanently displayed within the Church next to commemorative tablets for fallen soldiers of World War I.Ahead of the service, retiring officials hope to locate the exact date that the Peebles branch was formed for inscription on a plaque.Mr Stark explained: "We believe the branch was formed in  but we dont have records of the exact date."If anyone has any information on the forming of the branch we would like to hear from them."

title: musical-masterpieces-gala-39-s-best-kept-secret
story: ONE of the Scottish music scenes best kept secrets has emerged yet again from its Galashiels laboratory.Electron Mass has just released its fourth quartet of atmospheric mini-masterpieces.And while they wont be troubling the commercial airwaves or the even more commercial charts, yet again this duo and their friends have made their mark.Songwriters Sorensen Small and Brendan McAndrew use Electron Mass as an outlet for their unusual collaborations about science, nature and the cosmos.In their previous carnation, Small and McAndrew produced a stunning album as the Stone Ghost Collective.While they have moved the focus of their microscope away from unrequited love, they have managed to maintain something beautul with compositions about space, the Earth, the human mind and death.As Electron Mass, they released three wonderful EPs - Earthlight, Luminous and Selene - during .Last week they added to their canon for the curious with four more instantly appealing, yet erse, songs, neatly packed together as The Dopamine Girl EP.Each compelling composition while dferent from the next, encompasses beautul orchestration and haunting harmonies.And while it may take a degree or two to decipher the cryptic cantations, as with the previous EPs, The Dopamine Girl is a press repeat type of listen.Title track Dopamine Girl is, in their words, a short and sweet alternative-pop song... We knew it would last forever, but forever had its day.The Twin Peaks-inspired Love Dilation is as dark as it is atmospheric.But it is perhaps the utterly engrossing simplicity of Imprints that makes it so special. While McAndrew has the harmonic range, Smalls almost monotoned meanderings, accompanied by the backing vocals of Grant Pringle and Cameron Jack, creates the rawest of emotions.Concluding the new EP is the orchestral art-song, A Theory of Everything. Built around a single, beautully menacing chord, which apparently symbolises the background radiation in our universe, the finale discusses the search for discovering a unying theory of everything.To quote Small from Imprints, As you travel through space, you are displaced, imagining time. You exist like a plant, you bloom and you grow, then wither and die. But the one card you play, genetically, is always an ace. For the imprints you leave, have changed the fabric of time and space.If there is any justice in the supersonic space-age future, Electron Masss four EPs will hopefully have changed the fabric of music down here on Earth.

title: storms-expected-batter-borders-weekend
story: A WEATHER warning and a flooding alert have been issued for the Scottish Borders today.The storms are also expected to continue throughout the weekend.Heavy rain has already left many roads with deep standing water.And water courses throughout the region are starting to rise.A spokesman for the Scottish Environmental Protection Agencysaid: "A band of heavy, persistent rain will push northward from the early morning across southern and central Scotland on Friday."This may lead to localised flooding from surface water and smaller rivers."Built up areas and the transport network are at greater risk where possible impacts could include: flooding of low-lying land, roads, properties and disruption to travel particularly around the Friday morning rush hour."Further heavy and thundery showers are likely to develop across the area later on Friday and Saturday."A yellow warning for rain is in force today from the Met Office.A rain and thunder warning is in place for tomorrow while a thunder warning has been issued for Sunday.

title: b712-closed-following-two-vehicle-collision
story: THE B has reopened following a two-vehicle crash.The collision happenednear Stobo Castle at around .am.A child was been taken to hospital as a precaution and other occupants of the vehicles are reported to have suffered only minor injuries.Scottish Borders Council treated the road for an oil spillage before it re-openedearlierthis afternoon.

title: hearing-held-barrel-law-wind-farm-plans
story: A HEARING has been held by Scottish Government officials to discuss the proposed new wind farm at Barrel Law, near Hawick.In September, plans for an poundm wind farm were rejected by Scottish Borders councillors.The proposal would have seen seven turbines, of up to m in height, erected on land to the north-west of Roberton, near Hawick.The company behind the plans, Germany-based ABO Wind, then submitted an appeal to the Scottish Governmentrsquos planning and environmental appeals ision .As part of that appeal process, the DPEArsquos appointed reporter Elspeth Cook held a hearing at Forman Hall, Roberton.However, the hearing was simply to clary and define legal terms and certain technical standards in order to help inform Ms Cookrsquos decision.For example, one point of contention between Scottish Borders Council and ABO Wind is whether or not the combined appearance of Barrel Law and the existing wind turbines at Langhope Rig will create a lsquolandscape with wind turbinesrsquo or a lsquowind turbine landscapersquo, as per the legally-defined definitions.The councilrsquos position is that a distance of between -km is required in order to maintain the current landscape type in the valley, but ABO Wind suggest the turbines should be less than km apart, as they state that spreading out the two turbine sites would actually make the landscape look more saturated as the wind turbines would effectively cover a larger area.Furthermore, they state that a greater distance between the two developments would push the Barrel Law turbines outside of the topography which makes wind farms viable in this area.Appearing as part of ABO Windrsquos  of representatives, land and development consultant James Welsh told the reporter: ldquoIn our opinion we preserve the distinct identity of the two groups.ldquoThere are examples of wind farms being approved with similar distances between them but still being accepted as being clearly separate wind farms.ldquoTo insist on a greater separation would increase the effect of a cumulative effect between them.Scottish Borders Councilrsquos planning consultant, Dr Guy Wimble, said: ldquoI donrsquot dispute that they are identiable as separate elements, my issue is the effect of the wind farms on the landscape, and recognising that they are two dferent wind farms not one development.ldquoThe proximity of them makes this appear more of a wind farm landscape rather a landscape with wind farms.ldquoWhile I accept that separating the developments would make the wind farms seem more spaced out, by putting them closer yoursquod increase density.John Campbel QC, appearing on behalf of a group of objectors called Barrel Law Action Group, said: ldquoIf you pull the wind farms apart then clearly you increase the area of cumulative effect.ldquoIf you pull them together, yoursquore going to increase the cumulative effect just by sheer numbers, and you lose the ability to discern the two as distinct entities.Melrose and Leaderdale councillor Tom Miers, appearing in his capacity as Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive member for planning and environment, told the hearing: ldquoIt seems to me that the guidance allows for developments in this area but doesnrsquot necessarily promote it.ldquoNo one is disputing that the two wind farms would be separate, wersquore working to find out what degree of separation would be appropriate.Mr Welsh responded: ldquoIf you increase to a km distance it will push all m turbines outwith the area that has been identied as having the appropriate topography for this type of development.Ms Cook also sought clarication on certain technical points, mostly surrounding tables and figures contained within ious reports submitted by the appellant and the local authority.

title: art-thou-shakespeare-cyclists
story: BORDERS venues are to welcome the worldrsquos only cycling Shakespeare company this Autumn.Each summer the HandleBards acting troupes cycle riotously funny versions of Shakespearersquos classics across the UK.And after a quick stop off at the Edinburgh Fringe, they are moving onto the Borders and the rest of Scotland.This year, the HandleBards present The Tempest and Much Ado About Nothing to two Border towns.Each troupe is made up of four actors who cycle up to  miles a day, then set up their show, perform it, take down the set, then collapse in a heap!As the troupes have to take it slow, they get a sense of each area they perform in, saying lsquowe meet lovely localsrsquo and that they have even been known to lsquohunt down some wild swimming locations in the Bordersrsquo.Firstly, the all-female troupe will bring their lsquocompletely barmyrsquo The Tempest to Kailzie Gardens in Peebles.Then the all-male troupe will bring their witty Much Ado About Nothing to Bowhill House, outside Selkirk.The HandleBards take on the Tempest imagines Prospero as a faded vaudevillian magician, whose tricks have somewhat lost their lustre.Combining romance, music, real magic tricks and four tour-de-force performances, this show is one for the young, the old and everyone in between.While the troupersquos version of Much Ado About Nothing includes music, dancing and a lot of silly characters.Audiences are warned to look out for the dastardly Don Jon and look out for the HandleBards plundering your picnic.After forming in , the touring Shakespeare group have gone on to perform to over , people in castles, gardens, museums and public amphitheatres.Jack, Producer for The HandleBards, told us: ldquoWersquove performed in the Borders every year since the HandleBards started in , and we always receive a warm welcome.ldquoWe are excited to perform at some breathtakingly beautul venues - the majestic Bowhill House, and the bucolic Kailzie Gardens.ldquoWe love performing in the Borders area, itrsquos really a milestone for us, moving from our extensive English and Welsh touring, then breaking into beautul Scotland.ldquoIt usually means wersquove got about a third of the tours left, which is welcome news for our heroic troupes, who will each have cycled  miles already!Since they began, the group has cycled over , miles across the whole of the UK.And this autumn they will surpass the ,-mile mark with both productions.They are proud to be the only theatre company to combine sustainability and Shakespeare, while leading the way on achieving accessible and affordable theatre for all ages.Jack added: ldquoWhile the biggest theatre festival in the world takes place in Edinburgh, wersquore proud to bring theatre to venues all over Scotland and the Borders.ldquoOur all-female The Tempest is completely barmy, and totally magical.ldquoAnd our all-male Much Ado About Nothing is a witty, fast paced romp through one of Shakespearersquos best-loved plays.ldquoOur Scottish audiences are always brilliant, and wersquod love to get as many people along to this Summerrsquos shows as possible.Much Ado About Nothing takes place at Bowhill House on September  at .pm.The Tempest will take place at Kailzie Gardens on August  at .pm.Tickets for both shows can be found at https:www.handlebards tickets

title: thank-lucky-stars-dean-friedman-39-s-coming-st-boswells
story: HE was one of the voices of the s - and you can thank your Lucky Stars hes coming to St Boswells Village Hall.New Jersey-born Dean Friedman has retained a cult following since his stream of hits in the late s.This week his epic -date tour of the UK and Ireland takes him to the Edinburgh Festival for three nights before arriving at St Boswells Live on Saturday.Last year marked Deanrsquos th anniversary in the music industry, where he celebrated with a sold-out UK tour and the re-release of his digitally remastered,  ground breaking album Well, Well, said the Rocking Chair.On this latest tour Friedman will be performing solo, on guitar and keyboards, featuring songs from throughout his four decade recording career, including his classic hits Lucky Stars, Lydia, McDonaldrsquos Girl, Ariel and Woman of Mine, as well as selections from his last studio album,  Songs.Doors open for Dean Friedman at St Boswells Live at .pm on Saturday.Tickets, priced at pound and pound for concessions, are available at the Old Post Office in St Boswells or online at Music Glue.And IF any remain they will be available to purchase on the door on the evening of the concert.

title: paxton-house-opens-39-s-doors-trust-members
story: ONE of the Bordersrsquo most historic homes can now be enjoyed for free by members of the National Trust for Scotland.National Trust for Scotland is a charity that protects Scotlandrsquos national and natural treasures.Now members can enjoy the exquisite Paxton House in Berwickshire free of charge.Conservation charity members can explore all that the Palladian mansion has to offer, including its nationally signicant collection of Chippendale and Trotter furniture and masterpieces from the National Galleries of Scotland.And children can enjoy the Teddy Trail that runs throughout the house.Paxton House is owned and managed by Paxton Trust, a charitable trust that also manages the -acre estate set on the banks of the Tweed.In the extensive grounds there are gardens, woodland, an adventure playpark and even a den building area, plus the Stables Tearoom and the Regency Gt shop.Ian Marrian, Chairman of the Paxton Trust, said: ldquoThe team at Paxton House are excited to share this Borders treasure with members of the National Trust for Scotland and we look forward to welcoming them soon.National Trust for Scotland members can now show their valid membership upon arrival for free access to Paxton House.Mark Bishop, Director of Customer  Cause for the National Trust for Scotland, said: ldquoWersquore so pleased that Paxton House is throwing its doors open to our members who will love its beautul collections and interiors, and gorgeous grounds.ldquoThis gives our members even more reason to explore the Borders and the beautul places we protect here, for the love of Scotland.Also protected by the National Trust for Scotland are St Abbrsquos Head National Nature Reserve, Robert Smailrsquos Printing Works in Innerleithen, and Harmony Gardens in Melrose.

title: borders-families-urged-make-water-bottles-part-back-school-regime
story: PARENTS in the Borders are being encouraged to ensure their kidsrsquo back to school regime includes a new key item, a reusable water bottle.Along with the standard new unorm, gym kit and pencil case, a reusable water bottle is said to be a vital component for a childrsquos learning.Acclaimed Scots health and nutrition expert Amanda Hamilton is supporting a drive by Scottish Water to remind both parents and children of the benefits of taking a reusable water bottle to use at school.Best-selling lestyle author Amanda is also a mother-of-two and is concerned children do not drink enough water throughout the day.She said: ldquoEncouraging children to have a regular water intake throughout the school day is a vital aspect to maintain good health and a healthy learning environment.ldquoIt has been proven that through drinking water and staying hydrated children are more attentive and focused during lessons for longer periods of time.ldquoWe are lucky to have safe and delicious water from the tap, we should all be making the most of it. For parents trying to wean kids off sugary drinks, it can help to add a slice or orange, lemon or even a sprig of mint to tap water for extra flavour.For children aged five to eight years old the recommended water intake is one litre a day.The amount increasing even more to one and a half litres for eight to -year olds and up to two litres for over rsquos.And with the new p deposit scheme for throwaway drinks containers being rolled out in the Borders this year, reusable water bottles will not only save families money, but also teach children to respect the environment.Amanda added: ldquoLike many families, in my home we do all we can do reduce the use of plastic. Wersquove made it part of the daily routine to re-fill water bottles from the tap.ldquoBy highlighting the benefits of a reusable water bottle and filling up from the tap, we are helping to instil in children the small daily habits that can make a big dference.ldquoThe reality is that this is message for all ages ndash so using a reusable water bottle is just as applicable for people ing to work or students going back after the summer.Brian Lironi, Director of Corporate Affairs at Scottish Water, said: ldquoWe want to encourage everyone to choose our nationrsquos greatest natural asset, which is our fresh and tasty water - straight from the tap.ldquoWe believe thateveryone joins in, the positive impact on Scotland and the world will be incredible. Every little thing makes a dference.

title: accomplished-borders-musicians-bring-international-flair-bowden
story: Award-winning Borders musicians will get toes tapping with a fusion performance in Bowden this weekend.Multi-talented instrumentalists, Paul Chamberlain and Michael Haywood, will be delighting audiences at a concert in Bowden Village Hall on Friday.With a fresh take on world music Chamberlain  Haywood take their instruments on an international tour of the sultry sounds of the Tango, the rhythmic drive of the Balkans, along with rip-roaring tunes from Russia and Scotland.A promoter for the band commented: ldquoVirtuoso playing, and fresh musical ideas, Paul and Michael explore the potential of their instruments in a way that is exciting and engaging.ldquoThey take the strength of each instrumentrsquos traditions and blend them into their own unique brand of fusion music. The result is a vibrant, intriguing and occasionally explosive mix of music that crosses cultural boundaries.Both musicians grew up in the Borders, and a common interest in traditional music brought them together.Whilst still maintaining these traditional roots, the combination of Michaels jazz influenced style, and Pauls classical training come together to create a dynamic performance bursting with energy.Michael gained an honors degree in folk and traditional music from Newcastle University with a major in wind instruments.Since graduating, he has appeared at leading venues such as the Glasgow Royal Concert Hall, Sage Gateshead, The Barbican, and he has even played on BBC Radio Scotland.Now, Michael teaches music locally at Earlston High School.Paul was one of the first classical accordionists to graduate from the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland in Glasgow, where he graduated with a Master of Music Performance with Distinction.Whilst studying there he was awarded the acclaimed Governors Recital Prize for Keyboard and was also one of the keyboard section finalists in the  Royal Overseas League competition.Paul has made appearances at international music festivals such as Baltica Harmonica in St. Petersburg ndash Russia, Sata-Haumlme Soi Accordion festival in Ikaalinen ndash Finland, and the world-famous Edinburgh Fringe Festival.And he completed a major national tour of concerts in July  to coincide with his second CD release lsquoAccordion Sensationsrsquo.The concert takes place at Bowden Village Hall on Friday, August  at .pm.Tickets are pound for Adults and under rsquos go free.Chamberlain  Haywood will also be performing at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival on Sunday August .More information is available at www.chamberlain-haywood

title: ongoing-phone-issues-bgh
story: BORDERS General Hospital is experiencing ongoing telephone issues affecting incoming calls to departments within the hospital.The issue, which is due to a fault in BT lines serving the hospital, arose over the weekend.Whereas callers would ordinarily be able to phone wards and departments directly they are currently required to use the hospitalrsquos switchboard, resulting in delays.An NHS Borders spokesperson told the Border : ldquoWe are currently experiencing telephone line issues which is affecting external calls into the Border General Hospital.ldquoWe are liaising with BT who are currently working to resolve the issue with their systems.ldquoAnyone trying to contact a ward or department in the hospital should call the switchboard on   where our telephonists will put you through to the relevant department.ldquoDue to call demand you may experience a short wait.ldquoIf your call is about a medical emergency please call  for an emergency ambulance.

title: borders-licensed-premises-best-bar-none
story: Local licensed premises are being encouraged to raise the bar and join the Best Bar None Scotland Awards .A total of  premises in the Scottish Borders won  awards at a ceremony held in the Buccleuch Arms in St Boswells earlier this year.The awards recognised venues ranging from Eyemouth to Eddleston for their commitment to providing a safe and secure environment for the public.Best Bar None is open to pubs, bars, nightclubs, hotel bars and specialist entertainment venues - including community venues - in the local area.Best Bar None was developed by Greater Manchester Police in  as a response to increased violence and anti-social behaviour in and around licensed premises.It aimed to reward positive work within the licensed trade - improving standards and addressing local issues and, ultimately, keeping people safe.The scheme was adopted in Scotland in , initially in Glasgow, and is currently administered nationally by the Scottish Business Resilience Centre and by local co-ordinators.Councillor John Greenwell, Convener of the Scottish Borders Licensing Board, said: ldquoThere are a number of benefits to joining Best Bar None, namely the public awareness that an accredited premise is a quality venue which is serious about customer care and safety.ldquoThe process for signing up to Best Bar None Scotland has been made even more straightforward this year, with one application form for all types of premises.ldquoPolice Scotland and Scottish Borders Councilrsquos licensing standards officers are also available to assist participants at any stage.ldquoAnyone interested in applying should contact the Scottish Borders Safer Communities Team who will send someone out to go through the simple process with you.Entries can now be made via www.scotborders.gov.uk bestbarnone with successful premises being invited to the awards night held next year, which could then lead to a national Best Bar None Scotland award.Anyone wishing for more information should visit www.scotborders.gov.uk bestbarnone, phone   or email safercommunities@scotborders.gov.uk.

title: christine-gets-angel-wings-focus-centre
story: Murals of angels wings adorning the wall at the community centre in Galashiels have been painted as part of a worldwide public art movement.The Global Angel Wings Project has its roots in Los Angeles as a movement designed to engage the public with artwork and spread a little joy and happiness.Two angel wings murals, one adult and one child-sized, now adorn the outside wall at the focus centre.Members of the public are free to pose with the wings and, because it requires another person to capture the moment, it is hoped the wings will help encourage friendship and fun.They were painted by local artist Kirsten Boyle, who has a keen interest in public artwork, after a meeting with Galashiels employability charity Works+ led to the idea of a set of angel wings becoming a reality.Mark Timmons, Chief Operating Officer at works+ said: ldquoThe wings are part of a worldwide movement and we believe they are the first set in the Scottish Borders.ldquoThe Focus Centre is at the heart of the Galashiels community and the angel wings outwardly celebrate the amazing things that go on inside.ldquoArt is slowly becoming a big part of what goes on at the Focus Centre and the wings reflect this.ldquoWe hope that people will come along, get a photo taken with the angel wings and spread a little joy and positivity on social media.Local MSP Christine Grahame was only too happy to be snapped as the centrersquos first official angel. She said: ldquoI am delighted to be supporting The Focus Centre, and at last someone recognises that I have an angelic side!

title: sturgeon-set-beyond-borders-appearance-traquair
story: SCOTTISH First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is set to make an appearance at the th anniversary Beyond Borders International Festival.She will be interviewed by Allan Little at Traquair House on Sunday, August , in a session looking at Brexit, the current political landscape in Scotland, the United Kingdom and beyond.Alongside the First Minister, this yearrsquos Beyond Borders International Festival programme draws inspiration from a erse range of women who are making waves in current affairs, history, peacebuilding, literature and the arts from all over the world, including former participants from throughout the last ten years of the event.In the main tent, The New York Timesrsquo Stephen Dunbar-Johnson will chair a  co-curated with Sophie Lambin from the Womenrsquos Forum, which will focus upon the importance of womenrsquos leadership at the forefront of climate action.In Traquair Housersquos Walled Garden, a selection of the striking Carbonrsquos Casualties photographic exhibition by Josh Haner will be on display in the open air throughout August.Elsewhere in the programme, BBC journalist Razia Iqbal will be ing to talk to award-winning journalist Lindsey Hilsum about her book In Extremis which explores the extraordinary le and death of war correspondent Marie Colvin.They will also be discussing Hilsumrsquos impressive journalistic career capturing the stories of le on the front line from Rwanda in  to more recently, conflict in Syria and Ukraine.Audiences will also be joined by Ruth Wishart, who will interview Rosemary Goring about her book Scotland: Her Story, which seeks to address a patriarchal historical imbalance with stories of famous Scottish women such as Queen Margaret and Nicola Sturgeon, telling the story of Scotland through the women who have helped to shape it.Supported by the First Minister, Beyond Borders Scotland annually hosts three cohorts of female leaders from conflict communities in the Women in Conflict  Fellowship.The August  cohort will join the Festival weekend as part of their week focusing on the importance of the arts and cultural dialogue as a tool for peace building and conflict resolution.Audiences will be able to listen in as the Fellows share their stories across a iety of events, including Walled Garden storytelling events curated by tenx, and readings from contemporary Kurdish poet, translator and painter Choman Hardi.The Walled Garden also plays host to a iety of women-led and focused cultural events.The New York Times photojournalism exhibition ThisIs, launched on the International Day of the Girl in October , will be on display in the exhibition tent throughout the weekend.The project empowered female photographers to capture what le is like for girls turning  in their communities around the world.Local singer-songwriter Millie Hanlon-Cole will be delighting audiences with her enchanting selection of songs at lunchtime on Sunday, August .Mark Muller Stuart, Founder of Beyond Borders, said ldquoWe are looking forward to welcoming audiences back to Traquair House, and to showcasing a wealth of local and international talent in a programme of discussion and debate, alongside visual and performing arts, music, film and food and drink in the beautul surroundings of the Walled Garden.The full Beyond Borders Scotland Summer Events Programme and Box Office is available online at www.beyondbordersscotland

title: hawick-set-celebrate-borders-poet
story: A MULTIMEDIA event at Heart of Hawick is set to celebrate the le of poet Will H Ogilvie.Well Road Productionsrsquo latest work, lsquoWillrsquo, complements a series of events which take place this year to commemorate the th anniversary of Ogilviersquos birth.In four scenarios, the performance explores his le and adventures.Ogilviersquos childhood, his time in Australia, time at home in his beloved Borderland and his time as an elder statesman will all be explored.Ogilvie was born in Roxburghshire in  and died in Selkirkshire at the age of , but in between he travelled and worked in the outback and became known as one of Australiarsquos most famous poets.He wrote over  poems, including A Scotch night, The Australian, and Summer country.Paul Brough, Archives Manager at Live Borders said, ldquoWill H Ogilvie has an unusual place in Borders culture an important Australian balladeer, as much at ease in Australiarsquos Bush as in his home territory of Roxburgh and Selkirk.ldquoIt is exciting to celebrate his anniversary with an event of words and music.Eckford-based Well Road Productions is a small charity whose aims are to contribute to the preservation, promotion, education and understanding of the culture, history and heritage of the Borderlands and Scotland as a whole.lsquoWillrsquo will be performed at . on Friday, August , at Heart of Hawick.Musical support will be provided by Ian Lowthian.Tickets: pound.. Available from the Heritage Hub, Hawick, localhistory@liveborders.org.uk, and  .

title: no-plan-waste-transfer-station-vehicle-routes
story: ROAD safety campaigners are worried someone will be killed by a lorry heading to the waste transfer station at Easter Langlee ndash as it emerged vehicle routes have not been considered.John Birnie and Tom Douglas believe all three routes leading to the site are currently unsuitable for heavy goods vehicles.And they have written to council bosses to voice their concerns and ask how the project was approved without a preferred option being identied.Mr Birnie, of Coopersknowe Crescent, said: ldquoI donrsquot understand how they could say the roads are safe, when they are now telling us there was never a plan. They have got the choice of three roads. The first is the C, which is impossible. Somebody would get killed every day.ldquoThe second is the Lowood Bridge and that is unsuitable.ldquoIf anybody is on that bridge, how will a -tonne lorry be able to pass  If it tried to squeeze through, it would hit the people and would crush them.ldquoThe other option is bringing the traffic through the town and the community of Galashiels does not want that.ldquoThe roads were not built for that use. It is dangerous.ldquoThere never has been a route proposed on this application and there is still not one to this day.ldquoSo how could it have been approved, without knowing where the traffic is going Melrose community councillor Mr Douglas claimed SBC was ldquounnecessarily endangering the publicrsquos lives and putting financial expedience before public safety in a letter to council chief executive Tracey Logan.And he asked to see a copy of a lsquopre-planning application decisionrsquo on potential vehicle routes.But, in a response, Ms Logan said: ldquoI have been advised no such document exists.She added the council had considered a transport statement and a report from the public consultation process.However, she admitted: ldquoNo detail of vehicle routes was included within either document. This was principally because at the time of the planning application, the contract for removing and treating wasted had not yet been awarded, meaning that the end destination was not known.ldquoThe council has recently awarded the contract for waste recycling to Levenseat, a company based near Forth in North Lanarkshire. Levenseat will consider dferent routes at dferent times of the day, depending on circumstances such as traffic.... We anticipate Levenseat will determine the best routes over the coming weeks.An SBC spokesperson added: ldquoThe number of trips to the waste transfer station is largely in line with trips to the previous landfill site, and signicantly less than could have been generated by an integrated waste management facility at Easter Langlee.ldquoAs part of the planning application which was approved in November , the council committed to improving the road network through additional street-lighting, better signage, localised road widening and removal of trees and vegetation, all of which have taken place.ldquoThe council was not able to define a route during the planning process as the procurement exercise had not been completed and therefore SBC did not know the end destination or the preferred route.ldquoThe new residual waste contract will see the majority of the waste treated to produce a refuse derived fuel ndash to generate heat and electricity ndash as well as recover materials which can be recycled.ldquoThe closure of the landfill site and opening of waste transfer station will also see a reduction in harmful greenhouse gases from landfilling the waste and we believe it will also result in an improved recycling performance.

title: innerleithen-set-17th-annual-music-festival

title: borders-road-workers-strike-later-month
story: BORDERS roadworkers are set to strike later this month over changes to their local authority terms and conditions.Balloted members of the Unite union voted in favour of both strike actionand action short of a strikeback in June.And they have confirmed the industrial action will take place on Thursday, August , to coincide with the meeting of the full council.A rally and protest will also take place outside SBC Headquarters at Newtown St Boswells.The workers claim Scottish Borders Council imposed cuts to pensionable overtime rates and removal of paid travel time in April without any consultation.

title: new-machine-installed-bgh-thanks-fundraising-group
story: A NEW machine which treats debilitating skin conditions has been installed at Borders General Hospital ndash thanks to a group of fundraisers.The Friends of the BGH helped rack-up more than pound, to buy the PUVA machine which is used for eczema, psoriasis and lymphoma.Before the installation, NHS Borders was the only mainland trust not to have the ultraviolet light apparatus, meaning patients were forced to travel to Edinburgh for treatment.Dr Simone Laube, consultant dermatologist at NHS Borders: "Having this treatment available locally will mean Borders patients are provided with a full range of treatment options and the effects of the treatment can be le changing and in some cases, le saving."We are therefore extraordinarily grateful to the Friends of the BGH for fundraising to support this invaluable and worthwhile treatment for our Borders patients."In April the Friends of the BGH also helped raise funds for nine Lecard machines for the hospitals physiological measurement department ndash costing more than pound,.Austin Ramage, lead clinical physiologist said: "These devices are widely used and integral to assessing Borders patients for heart rhythm issues and these additional devices are absolutely vital to the service as we move forward."Thanks go to the Friends of the BGH and all those who have participated in the fundraising activities for these devices."James Majoribanks, chairman of the Friends of the BGH group added: "The Friends of the BGH has been donating equipment etc for the benefit of our local hospital for many, many years and we are grateful for the many fundraising events which take place all over the Borders during the year."We are currently raising money for a bladder scanner in Ward , which again will be an immense help to the patients and nurses in that ward."We are always looking for volunteers to help us raise money for the BGH and would welcome anyone wishing to volunteer to join the committee."Please contact me at jym@hoggandthorburnyou wish to help andyou wish to donate, please go to www.justgiving friendsofbgh."

title: call-later-buses-galashiels-peebles
story: PEEBLESSHIRE bus users could be able to stay in Galashiels after darkthere is sufficient demand for a late service.Currently the last bus from Galashiels to Peebles is at .pm weekdays and Saturday, and .pm on Sundays.The possibility of introducing a later bus is being investigated and community councils are trying to establishthere is a desire for this so they can present it to Scottish Borders Council.Peebles Community Council asked locals for feedback and the overwhelming response was that a late service was needed for social, educational and work purposes.Many residents took to social media to say staff that work at the Borders General Hospital often struggle with transport when working late shts.Others said they would use the cinema in the town more as they could see later showings, whilst some said it would allow them to attend evening courses at college.Peebles Community Councillor Scott Rae said there was a huge response from the public.He added: ldquoThere is a lot of support for that idea but obviously its translating support into whether people will actually use it. I think itrsquos worth us putting together a survey to see what the demand threshold is likely to be.

title: frank-zappa-tribute-band-head-macarts
story: RETURNING after last years success, Pygmy Twylyte will present a must-see music event at the end of the month.While local rockers South of Sanity will be opening the show.After a successful first year together the Scottish seven-strong band are back to keep Frank Zappa music alive.With guitars, keyboards, saxes and a xaphoon at their disposal, the band has a foot planted in the camp of title: innerleithen-honours-a-true-st-ronanite
story: A PLAQUE has been unveiled in Innerleithen to remember a prominent businessman from the town.Murray Allan, who founded textile firm Murray Allan of Innerleithen Ltd, died at the age of  in .And on Saturday a special memorial was revealed at Cleikum Mill ndash the building which housed his firm for almost  years.It was unveiled by his widow May, in front of a large crowd of proud family members and friends.Mr Allanrsquos daughter Elizabeth Rae told the Peeblesshire News: ldquoWe were amazed at how many people turned up and felt extremely proud that Murray was held in such high regard.ldquoMemories and stories were shared and Irsquod not be surprisedmore reunions arise from the day.Mr Allan set up the business, which specialised in cashmere knitwear, back in .And it provided more than  jobs for the town.Ms Rae explained: ldquoMurray Allan of Innerleithen Ltd produced highly prestigious garments and was globally very successful.ldquoIt was awarded the Queenrsquos Award for Export Achievement in , and attracted royal visits from Prince Charles, Princess Anne and the Duke of Kent.ldquoMurray sadly died in  at the age of , but was there for the visit of Prince Charles.ldquoWe invited all surviving employees to attend the ceremony.ldquoThe only ones who could not come were those who were either on holiday on the day or are aged and were too ill to be there.ldquoMost of the workforce were local to Innerleithen and knew Murray and all the Allan family well. Many were also married couples and some were whole families ndash in fact the company was one big, proud family.

title: leading-country-music-tribute-acts-mosey-galashiels

title: government-criticised-spending-10m-brexit-advertising-campaign
story: Ministers have been criticised for spending more than pound million over eight months on an advertising campaign to help people and businesses prepare for Brexit.Figures released to the PA news agency under Freedom of Information laws showed the Government spent pound,, on their Prepare For EU Exit adverts between November  and July this year.The Cabinet Office spent pound. million on print, pound. million on radio, pound. million on TV and more than pound million on social media advertising, and a further pound million on other s, according to the data.The figures also revealed that the page advising people living in the UK on how to prepare received . million views by the end of May, while the EU citizens preparedness tool had , views.Labourrsquos Wes Streeting told PA the money would have been better spent on public services.He said: ldquoEvery single penny spent on this advertising campaign to prepare for the self-inflicted damage that is Brexit would have been better spent on policing, schools and the NHS.ldquoBrexit is already costing us dearly and we havenrsquot even left yet.Independent MP Heidi Allen also criticised the cost, saying taxpayersrsquo money was being ldquowasted on desperately attempting to sell a catastrophic no-deal to the public when it ldquocould have been spent on school books, medicines or stretched local authorities.ldquoWhat kind of government prioritises spending on persuading the public that the harm of a no-deal is a price worth paying ldquoBut it wonrsquot work. No matter how much public money Boris Johnson squanders, he will not be able to hide the damage of a no-deal from the businesses, public services and communities that will be hit hardest by it.ldquoThis woeful waste of public money is another reason why it is essential for voters to give their consent in a final say vote.Labour Party chairman Ian Lavery added: ldquoNine months on and pound million later our country is no further forward.ldquoThe Tories have bungled negotiations and they have no plan except to prolong our agony with a costly no-deal Brexit.A Government spokesman said: ldquoWe have stepped up preparations to ensure we are ready for Brexit and we have been reviewing the guidance we are issuing across Whitehall to ensure we are fully prepared for leaving on  October, whatever the circumstances.ldquoIt is paramount that organisations, communities and citizens have the right information and support for Brexit.ldquoWe will soon launch a large-scale public information campaign setting out what business and the public need to know and do to be fully prepared for Brexit.The disclosure comes as an estimated pound million has been devoted to a new information campaign under Boris Johnsonrsquos administration, helping people and businesses get ready to leave on October ..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Government criticised for spending  xAm on Brexit advertising campaign

title: campbeltown rallies to independence march
story: The independence march through Campbeltown on Saturday was a huge success and put a real zest for le back into the town which has been too long forgotten.That was the view of organiser Manny Singh who despite his apparent sacking from the All Under One Banner organisation was very much still in charge at the Campbeltown march.Afterwards he said: #It was a huge success for Campbeltown and the biggest demonstration for decades. There was a lot of spirit and a feeling that a number of towns in Scotland which have been forgotten, like Campbeltown, will not be left behind after independence.#He put the turnout at more than , and added: #The fact that the march extended theof Longrow gives a fair indication of the numbers who were there.He also told the Courier this week that he remained the #legal indentity# of the All Under One Banner group, despite a bitter public row among the hierarchy which looks like splitting the group in two.It was the biggest rally held in the town in recent years with marchers coming from as far afield as Aberdeen and Alloa and as well as Oban, Glasgow and Islay, with many travelling on the weekend ferry from Ardrossan.#It really exceeded expectations and made a big splash in the town, Ron Wilson of Yes Kintyre told The National.#There was a real buzz as people came early and most of the hotels were booked up. The pubs and cafes were busy so it was good for local businesses. Campbeltown is a Yes town and it was brilliant to have all these people come here. Local people were coming off the pavements and joining the procession so it created a good, positive vibe.Pro-Unionists opponents held their own counter demonstation. However, the march went off without any incident and there were no arrests, with only one warning which was drug related.A spit of rain earlier in the day failed to develop into poor weather as the marchers would round the town to hear speakers and listen to musicians at the rally at Kinloch Green.Mr Wilson said he was particuarly pleased at the turnout as there had been some confusion over whether the march would go ahead due to internal sions within the hierachcy of All Under One Banner, which has organised independence marches across the country.Following Mr Singh#s sacking, founder Neil Mackay resigned from his position on its national executive pending an internal investigation.Pro-UK Unionist group A Force For Good met the march on the shore front and say they filmed and counted the marchers, as they have at previous events, and afterwards claimed the turnout was just .Director, Alistair McConnachie, said: #All Under One Banner is basically the marching wing of the SNP. AUOB, and SNP MPs and MSPs, lie about the numbers which attend their marches, sometimes up to  or  times.#Unfortunately, they are not challenged by the Scottish media. The good news is that A Force For Good has a presence at every AUOB march. title: cricketer liam chases his world cup dream
story: A young cricket star with Campbeltown connections has been starring for Scotland under-s in the team’s quest to qualy for the World Cup.Teenager Liam Naylor # who lives in Liverpool but whose mother Marie Naylor is originally from Campbeltown # and his compatriots have been in The Netherlands for a week-long qualying round that has seen them take on the host country, as well as Ireland, France, Jersey and Denmark.And while Liam, , began playing the game in Merseyside with Alder Cricket Club at the age of , rising through the ranks to turn out for the club’s first team as a seam bowler at , he has since earned a two-year scholarship to play cricket and study sport at the Wellington School, in Taunton, Somerset, after being scouted by Steffan Jones, a household name in English county cricket as a fast bowler, and as a coach in Indian cricket for Rajasthan Royals.As an avid Liverpool FC fan, Liam regularly attends matches at Anfield with his mum, sister Hannah and football-mad dad Phil Naylor, but Marie explained how Liam’s love for batting sports also runs in the family.Marie said: ‘I spent many happy summers playing rounders with my friends on Meadows Field growing up, and coming back to Campbeltown Liam would always want to play cricket # not rounders, but cricket # on that same field.‘Liam has already represented Scotland under-s, so to go away with the under-s is another really exciting opportunity. We’re really proud of him.’Earlier in the week, Liam and teammates defeated both the Netherlands and Jersey, with all-rounder Liam scoring a superb  runs against the Channel Islanders. The group winners will qualy for next year’s ICC Under- Cricket World Cup in South Africa.
